rss.title: Homosexuality Part II
rss.subtitle: The most important question of our generation...continued

subtitle_detail.value: The most important question of our generation...continued

transcription.full_transcript: Welcome to Catholic Stuff You Should Know, a Jade 10 initiative. Hey, and welcome. This is Catholic Stuffing Show Middle Father John and my good friend Joe Doman here with you. Welcome back. Part two on the difficult topic of homosexuality. It's been a week and we're happy you're listening to this one. Many probably did not shut it off after the part of the last one. But tonight we want to kind of continue the conversation, but shift more towards now practically. given all the facts, the statistics, the moral teaching, the ways we have to resist the approach to gay marriage and all these different things, now we kind of move towards, okay, what do you do if you have a son or a friend? Exactly. Or you encounter somebody who struggles with this. We all know, I mean, if you've gone to public high school or if you have gone to any high school or, I don't know, if you're in our generation in your 20s, early 30s like John, uh you have early 30s very um you've encountered this and you're going to continue kind of throughout the rest of your life uh and you're definitely encountering it if you're in america in the culture and um one of the things that is that i see okay so our last conversation um the which you led on the homosexuality uh and kind of the the statistics the church teaching around it um And the danger in focusing solely on that is that this issue becomes purely a cultural war or a political battle or something that's abstract. But it's also there's a war going on in hearts. There's a battle for individual souls that's going on. And I think when we speak solely on that level, we can tend to and this has been my frustration with how I have to say this. With how, at least in some circles in the church, this issue is talked about, because I feel like it's only talked about as a political issue, as a political reality. Gay marriage, we need to define marriage, we need to guard marriage, we need to protect marriage, which is totally, I'm totally fine with that. I'm totally cool with that. I think that's an important battle to fight. But we can't lose sight of the fact that there are people in the pews. who love Christ, may even love the church, and who have this struggle. There are people in our families, there are our friends, who this isn't a political issue for them. This is an issue of their own desires, their own shame, their own... their own souls, you know? So anyway, basically, that's why I think it's important. I'm glad we're doing this in two parts because it really is. There's really two topics. It's the political, the cultural, the gay marriage question, all those things. But it's also, what do you do when you meet someone? When it's someone in your family, when it's someone in your community, how do you be... Christ to them without just watering down the truth. Well, and that's what I think is the two extremes of heaven, because it's such a difficult situation to deal with that you either do one of two things. You either completely reject them, you completely freak out, and you just remove them from life, or you completely set aside all the church's teachings and any attempt, and you just say, we love you, we accept you, we're tolerant of you, and it becomes just... nothing. And I think the church, uh, as far as the church that's speaking in public life has erred more on the side of, let's just say the truth and let's be clear about it. Um, but what's, what's felt when, when the church, you know, say a bishop says the whole teaching of the church is teaching on gay marriage, uh, and, and same sex attraction with, with the love and the truth and everything, the media will take that. And all they'll take is All that's communicated to the public is churches against gays or church against gay marriage. Now, what I would say to that is that's true. The public persona of the church as the bishops is all about... this is the church teaching. We're standing to it. Let's, you know, which isn't bad. The media takes that. What's communicated though? The people in the pews, at least my experience of, of being a priest now for several years. Sure. They're the exact opposite. We have no backbone as Catholics. We are the first to say, show how tolerant and how accepting and how loving we are. The problem is not, there's a very small, fierce minority. of, I would say, who are really, really getting, at least in Denver, and I've been in Boulder for two years, so it's a very small minority, who I would say are too aggressive and too extreme in fighting it. And even in the way that some priests preach about it, they get too excessive. They do it too much. They do it too often. They don't do it the right way. But the 95% of the people that I see either don't believe what the church teaches, outrightly, or they're really ready to just show that we will throw this out. Right. And that's what I'm seeing in the church. Totally. So we have both extremes. Yeah. So anyway, but if you look at what the church is saying officially, I think it's very balanced. So this is from last week, John read 2357 from the catechism. Next paragraph, 2358. We're just going to kind of unpack this a little bit. So this is 2358 from the catechism. The number of men and women who have deep-seated homosexual tendencies is not negligible. So that's the first point, that this isn't a small minority. This is a minority. It kind of touches all of our lives. This inclination, which is objectively disordered, constitutes for most of them a trial. They must be accepted with respect, compassion, and sensitivity. Every sign of unjust discrimination in their regard should be avoided. These persons are called to fulfill God's will in their lives, and if they are Christians, to unite to the sacrifice of the Lord's cross for the difficulties they may encounter from their condition. Okay, so there are three things in there that I think are important. So if you're thinking, what do I do when a friend, loved one, son, brother, sister, whatever, has the struggle? Kind of three main points I can glean from this. The first one is acceptance of the person. And this is the catechism says they must be accepted with respect, compassion and sensitivity. This constitutes for most of them a trial, you know. And so except this is this is basically for many people who are not Christian or even for some people who are Christian, they have something in their head that if you're a Christian. you kind of have to be, you're uncomfortable with homosexuality, and you come across as a homophobe. And I've heard that accusation, and I've heard kind of Christians or Catholics kind of brush it off. But honestly, I look around and I'm like, I think there are homophobes in the church. I think there are people who don't know how to deal with it, and at least they come across, they're afraid of it. And so I think the first thing to realize is that, okay, to be Christian does not mean to be homophobic, and by that mean... Like, you don't need to freak out when someone manifests this struggle and confidence. Those I know who struggle with same-sex attraction, these are the churches. For most of them, it constitutes a trial. And so acceptance of the person, I think, is primary. And that goes even before they manifest anything. And this is how we should treat all people. accepting them where that, because for most of them, the struggle, uh, okay, you're, you're raised Catholic, you're raised Christian. Uh, this cultural political battle is going on or whatever you say, but you, you, and you look at your own heart and you say, I have these struggles, the struggles there. Um, and the thoughts that are going through their heads, at least the ones I've known is, uh, can I really be loved here? Like, am I even capable of loving? There's something wrong with me that I can't even love. Right. Um, everybody here seems to love me. The people were supposed to, quote unquote, supposed to love me, my family, my community. But if they knew this about me, would they still love me? Because of, you know, there's a lot of doubts. And you're immediately living a life in darkness of, like, being shielded from the love of others because you have something that has a lot of shame and guilt associated with it, even if it doesn't need to necessarily be, you know, even if you haven't done anything, acted on it. but, uh, so these are the struggles that a person will be dealing with. Uh, and so the response, when some manifest them manifest this desire or this same sex attraction as a struggle. Um, is not to like back away from them or to get weird around them or to love them any less. It's to reaffirm that they are loved despite this, uh, or in, you know, even with this, there's nothing they can do to make you love them less. No part about their struggles, whatever. I think that's the main thing to emphasize. Um, acceptance of the person though acceptance of the person is it is an important distinction and that's exactly and this is a distinction that the catechism draws out it doesn't say you have to accept the the gay lifestyle exactly and this is let me continue yeah so the next part of that i mean just say quit cutting me off yeah exactly stop cutting me off so the in the same paragraph though the church says this inclination which is objectively disordered right and so you you both accept the person but recognize I think we're afraid to call this a disorder. Yeah. I think, and if you read articles and you're reading literature on this, that's kind of a big battle here. Is this a disorder or not? And I think part of that, what do we mean when we say disordered? I think some people hear disordered and think, you know, like, this is a disorder. You know. equals you are kind of a monster or a freak or something. And the reality is that when we say disorder, we mean that in a very Catholic philosophical sense, meaning that we are made for an end. We are made for a purpose. God has created us in such a way and ordered us in such a way that our fulfillment is attained in a specific way, i.e., his plan for our lives. living life in Christ, ultimately fulfilling life in heaven and living the life of the Trinity. So when we say disorder, we're referring to something that is not in line with fulfilling that end. So that's all we're saying when we say disorder. It's objectively disorder because this tendency for same-sex attraction is disordered because it's a desire to act in a way which will not... bring me to ultimate happiness in Christ. But again, when disorder is played, when homosexual desires as disordered are in the context of All disordered sexual desires, which we all have. Exactly. When it's kind of given that normal place instead of kind of isolated from it, then it gives it more of a context and it makes more sense. Exactly. You're a freak and we have it all together. If you have a desire to, if a man has a desire to lust after a woman, that is an objectively disordered desire. Does that mean it's not normal? Well, yeah, I mean, it's kind of normal. Most guys, there's at least an inclination to, even if he's not acting on that. But it's a disordered desire because it's a tendency pointing in a direction that is not going to lead to my fulfillment. Right. That's what we mean. So when the church says that, don't take that as like the churches are bigots or when we're saying these people are disordered, this tendency is disordered. Or we're judging or we're blind to this. All the church is just making a claim about what man is made for. I do I will say like I am so sick of the liberal media. Like I'm sorry to go back. I'm the jerk in this. He's the nice guy, the pastoral guy. But like the media spins everything. I mean I see these bumper stickers everywhere. Hate is not a family value and it's all about we just hate and persecute. Let me tell you something. Like I will challenge any homosexual in Boulder, Colorado. to say that I experienced more persecution in two years there than they did any single person. I guarantee it. And so for the media to just make us out to be these horrible people that are just out hating people, I don't think it. I think the regular person listening to this podcast is saying, I believe what the church says. I'm trying to figure out how to make this happen. They're not. being rash and crazy. And so the church is so clear on this. Any unjust discrimination in their regard should be avoided. We could never. ever accept that. But I just, I want to kind of challenge your sensitivity on this because you're very sensitive to it, but I think it's so ridiculously blown out of proportion. No, I think, I agree with you and I don't think you need to challenge it because I think I'm saying the same thing. We don't, we need to stop being afraid of calling it a disorder. Right. Because I think the media has convinced us that, oh, we're hating when we do this. And the church isn't. What the church means by this is something very specific. It doesn't mean you're freaks. It doesn't mean we hate you or there's something. wrong with you and there's not something wrong with us. We're all kind of in this mess together and you have some disorders, I have other disorders, and this is one of them. This is one of the disorders that our family, the human family, is plagued with because of sin. That's one thing to remember too, that this isn't just a physical reality. There is demonic work. There is a demonic spirit at work here. As there is throughout all of humanity, we have an enemy. and he wants us to see what is good is evil and what is evil is good. And he wants us to point the finger and say, that is the enemy. And they're pointing the finger at us saying, they are the enemy. The reality is the enemy is not the liberal media. The enemy is not the gay culture. The enemy is Satan. And the liberal media, the people in the media, the people who are in the gay culture participating are casualties. Um, but it's just a good thing to keep that in mind because in the battle that's at work, there are a lot of poor who are suffering. We're on both sides of the fence, both sides of the line, however you want to draw it. So anyway, first thing, acceptance of the person. Second thing, recognizing there's a disorder and not being afraid of that and understanding what we mean by that. Um, and, um... The third thing that the church points to in this paragraph, the last thing they say, they say, these persons are called to fulfill God's will in their lives. And if they're Christians, to unite to the sacrifice of the Lord's cross, the difficulties they may encounter from their condition. So, you know, this constitutes a cross for their lives. And the church urges, To unite to this, the sacrifice of Christ's cross, their own sacrifices that arise from this condition. I have a friend of mine who has, you know, struggles with same-sex attraction, loves the church, Orthodox, good man, solid man. But I asked him as we, as I was kind of preparing and talking about this with him, I asked him, you know, what would you want me to say? If I had to say anything about homosexuality, same-sex attraction on this podcast. And he said, one thing interesting, he says, he says, speak about. the pastoral fruitfulness for the life of the church that can be attained by people who have this struggle. Because this is a great cross. And the church in her wisdom sees this as every cross, every suffering that someone experiences doesn't have to be this dry, tepid suffering. but it can be a suffering that is the suffering of a person united with the person of Christ for the salvation of the world. And that can be great. It's like he said, he's like, it's like there's... it's like there's so much potential for spiritual power from this, this struggle. If you need to lose. And he was saying from his own experience, when I've united to cross, it's been a huge source of grace in his life. And he was, so he's just encouraging. This was, and I read the catechism. I was like, Oh, that's actually what the church encourages too. So if you, if you have this struggle, if you find yourself struggling with same sex attraction, it's a real, it's a real cross that few of us can understand. It isolates you from other persons. It kind of can, cloud a lot of the ways that you feel like you're received by people or you receive others. It hits you at your deepest, part of your deepest core, your sexuality. A real cross. And so if you're dealing with somebody who has same-sex attraction, recognize that this is not something easy. great sensitivity around it. And if you have this struggle, recognize that you're not alone in this. And you can be, you can have the struggle and be Catholic knowing that you can have the struggle and be a saint. Yeah. You can have this struggle and unite your struggle to the cross of Christ and do incredible work for the church, just on a spiritual level with pastoral fruitfulness for the mission of the church. And I think that is a, that is such an important thing for people to hear. Anybody who would listen to this, you know, God willing, somebody who actually, you know, struggles with same-sex attraction, to hear that not only do you have a place in the church, but you have a privileged place because of the intensity of the cross that you bear. You know what I mean? Yeah. That is something that needs to be said and needs to be kind of encouraged because, again, the fruitfulness of the church stems from the cross, which is suffering, and Jesus gives us the invitation to bring these crosses to him and to unite them in him. And the church is the... the church's graces are dispensed from the crosses that people suffer. So it's beautiful. It's really important. And just finally, the, the last, there's one more paragraph on this. It's just a couple of one sentence, I think two sentences that the church says, homosexual persons are called to chastity by the virtues of self-mastery that teach them inner freedom at times by the support of disinterested friendship, disinterested friendship, meaning non-platonic friendships, friends who have their best interests in mind. by prayer and sacramental grace. they can and should gradually and resolutely approach Christian perfection. Beautiful. So they're called a chastity, just like we are as celibates, but just like all Christians are called to love chastely, you know. But it's interesting as a, Father John, I don't know if you can relate to this, but as a seminary now, as a deacon, when I've had conversations with men who have this struggle, I feel like it's much easier for me to say, hey, God's calling you to live. chastely you know if you can't because you're living because i'm like because the world tells us and the media tells us culture tells us you need sex to be happy right and we're so we never hear we just need a step and be like that is a lie yeah you do not need sex to have real friendship to have real love to have real joy uh there are sacrifices there are sacrifices no matter which way you turn if you have sex you're gonna have sacrifices um with children with all sorts of things but you do not need sex to be happy and i think that's what we're so it's so easy to be afraid to encourage people who have same-sex attraction. And one thing, and this is kind of a side note. the approach, some people are like, you know, if you have same-sex attraction, maybe you can be healed of this. Maybe you can be, maybe you can go to counseling and kind of get it worked out. It's true. There are some instances, uh, if you, um, father Harvey, who's worked a lot with, uh, I think in Chicago with, um, same-sex attraction and stuff like that, he's seen some results, but the majority of men who even have counseling can't change. Right. Uh, can't, they don't like have heterosexual desires all of a sudden. um it's a possibility but um for a young man unmarried uh there's a danger in trying to want to try to wanting to try to fix them when uh really like you can be have same-sex attraction, have these tendencies, and live chastely, live celibately, have a beautiful prayer life, have a life that's incredibly fruitful, and be just as much a member of the church and a community with the church as ever. And the church wants you. The church needs this. The church needs witnesses of men who have this struggle, and women. I don't mean to—we're speaking about men because that's who I've talked to the most about it. But— So yeah, the main thing though, if you're going to take away anything from this, this is the one thing I think is the crux of all what we said. It's very simple, but it's that the action, homosexual actions are sinful and disordered. homosexual tendencies, a desire, is not sinful. I think people just need to hear that. Because I've talked to several men who have this struggle, and they don't hear that. All they hear is that the church is against gay people. I think it's important to realize, like, if you have same-sex attraction and you think, you agree that marriage is between a man and a woman and that sex is only for marriage. when it comes to same-sex attraction, the church isn't saying anything more than that. We're not saying like, oh, and if you have this attraction, this tendency, you're going to hell or something like that. No, the church is just saying sex is made for marriage. Right. Marriage is between man and woman. Amen. So anyway. And to kind of close this out. Yes. And come full circle from the beginning of the first podcast. Back up to that camp, a bunch of college kids sitting around and we're talking about this. Ah, yes. Pray away the gay. Pray away the gay, not the answer. What do you say? And they say, what do we say to them? And I said, well, the first thing you have to realize is that if they're telling you this, this is probably the first time they've ever articulated it. And it's probably the deepest, most humiliating and embarrassing thing they've ever experienced about themselves. So the handling. of that first articulation is so important. Literally the way that they do that could make the difference between whether we run them out of the church, right. For the rest of their life and make them militantly, you know, anti-Catholic in, in the gay, you know, movement, or if they embrace it as their cross. and then have a profoundly fruitful life coming from their chastity. Profoundly fruitful. I told them that. I said, chastity is the source of friendship, according to the catechism. We've got to encourage them in that way. And so I said, you've got to be very, very delicate, very, very careful, but at the same sense, trying to articulate everything that we've been saying already and not to reiterate that again. And I think they understood that as, that's exactly right. It's what you described very well, which is acceptance of the person. but articulating that the disordered nature of the desire and then, and then the encouragement, the accountability and the support of friendship and Christian relationship to have self mastery over the desires and come to holiness in Christ. And that's, that's what we're talking about here. That's right. And so we need, and we need to talk about it. We need to, not just us, but like talk about it with, you know, your friends, with your, with your children when they're at appropriate age, but like people need to hear the truth about homosexuality and not just, because the media is talking all about it. Yeah. Um, and, and they're, they're receiving lies, you know, it's, it's, it's love without truth. Well, I'm going to preach on it this weekend. We'll see how it goes. It can't be as, it can't be as, uh, violent as they were to me in Boulder. So probably not. So anyways, that's enough for heavy topic. We'll have Gulb coming in next and talking about, I don't know. I don't know, raisins or something. Exactly. But we do appreciate emails, especially those of you who have been waiting a long time for this topic. Yes, always request a topic. And honestly, shoot us emails. Give us feedback about this. We could even have like, we could do a podcast just on like responses. I mean, if you have some thoughts, maybe something we missed, something you disagree with, something we said the wrong way, please let us know. and we'll respond for sure. But we appreciate your feedback always. CatholicStuffPodcast at gmail.com. Thanks for listening.

summarization.results: The discussion centers on homosexuality within the Catholic Church, emphasizing acceptance, respect, and support for individuals with same-sex attraction. It underscores the importance of distinguishing between accepting the person and acknowledging the inclination as objectively disordered, while encouraging living chastely and finding spiritual strength in struggles. The conversation highlights the need for truthful discussions, understanding the Church's perspective, and providing support within the church community.
